I call bs on the first riddle. Your question was which king would sink faster in water that was 25°f vs 25°c. It's supposed to be a trick question but the trick is invalid. 25°f WATER is not ice. Water is the common name for the liquid state of H²O. (I can't sub text the "2".) Ice is the common name of the solid form of the same molecule. Steam, the common name for its gaseous state. Ice, water and steam are NOT the same and therefore, you can't substitute one for the other to trick someone in this riddle.

On top of that, it's relatively simple to produce water that is 25°f. Simply place it under pressure and the molecule can stay liquid at lower temperature than the accepted, 32°f freezing point of water.

I expect a physics expert to know these things and employ rigid adherence to basic definitions and simple physical properties of matter. 😉

And as a sound engineer for over thirty years, the sound cancellation riddle is a well known property of sound. In the analog world we could almost accomplish full cancellation in studio equipment. With the advent of digital sound, it was one of the first tricks we played with because reversing phase on one of two identical tracks could demonstrate complete cancellation. Each track has it's own level meter. Both tracks show plenty of level, but the output channels of the virtual console show nothing sure to the cancellation. (And, consequently, no sound is heard from the monitor speakers. Cue up either track on its own and the sound can be heard, but together it's a lot of power that adds up to silence. I can demonstrate it physically, using only my hands, but it's hard to describe in words. If be happy to share, if you're interested.

It's fun to think about how you could mess with the solution to the chess piece/water bucket riddle.

1) From what material is the chess piece made? Most types of wood and some plastics will float in liquid water and neither would touch the bottom.
2) From what height are you dropping the pieces, and how tall and full is the bucket? If the piece floats, sufficient kinetic energy could carry it through a layer of water to bounce off the bottom of the bucket anyway.
3) With enough atmospheric pressure you can reduce the freezing point of water several degrees below 0° C. Not sure if you can go as low as 25° F, though. With additives you could definitely keep the water solution a liquid at 25° F.

I'm pretty sure she specified the clock had four digits, so 09:59 backwards would be 95:90 which is not even a valid time. 23:32 -> 00:00 is the shortest interval if you actually follow the rules as laid out in the riddle. Most intervals are 70 minutes (middle two digits both going up by one), thirteen of them, two intervals of 251 minutes (middle digits going from 5 to 0, outer digits going up by one) and one interval of 28 minutes (midnight). This is because there can be at most one palindrome per hour, and only on the hours that end in 5 or less because the third digit has to be 5 or less. This gives two sets of 6 palindromes, followed by a set of 4 because hours don't go past 23.

General objection to the solutions put forth so far the Sink the ping pong ball puzzle: If you are allowed to use additional equipment many of the solutions put forth seem like they might work (I'm skeptical of the black hole idea). The  vortex ideas may not require additional equipment but it may not be possible to do without splashing water out of the bowl  unless you use something to spin it up smoothly and then you've used an additional piece of equipment. Bowl riddle: Take a centre tube from a roll of paper towels. Nip a bit of a triangle out of the edge on one end of the roll. Slide the nipped end of the tube down over the floating ball. Proceed to blow air down the tube. Water will be forced out the triangle at the bottom and as the water is displaced, the ball will drop to the bottom of the bowl. A variation: Have a capped tube with small-diameter hose, e.g., from a fish tank at the bottom on one side and a similar diameter hole on the other side at the bottom. Place tube over ball and lower tube to bottom over sensor. Blow air into the hose. Because gas is lighter than water, we'll displace water out the exit hole till the ball will eventually contact our sensor.

The digital clock palindrome riddle wasn't well defined. I got a different solution:

On all the digital clocks I own, the first of the 4 digits is always shown, even if it is 0 (like right now in the upper right corner of my android phone). Thus, 09:59 is not a palindrome, but e.g. 01:10 would be one.

Moreover, I live in an area where we use the 24h system, not the 12h am/pm system.

Okay for the ping pong ball riddle: if you can't modify or touch the ball and you can't remove the water, this leads me to believe that you can modify the water.  According to Archimedes principle the bouyant force on the ping pong ball is equivalent to the volume displaced times the density of the fluid it is in (water).  So, the goal is to reduce the density of the water.  You could boil it, but I feel that would be counted as removing water.  You could also blow bubbles underneath the ping pong ball to attempt to reduce the effective density of the water underneath the ball, but I'm worried that won't be enough.  My only other though is to add another substance to the water that will reduce it's density significantly.

Thanks for more interesting riddles. Having never used the Fahrenheit system, I did over think the first riddle. As liquids expand (mostly) when heated, I was thinking the warmer liquid would be less dense and therefore provide less buoyant force and allow it to sink quicker. I think it might also have reduced viscosity and therefore provide less drag as the objects sink. But then I thought about the objects being used, and as chess pieces are typically wood or plastic, I think they would float on the liquid water and therefore neither touches the bottom.
For the last riddle, creating a fast enough vortex would of course allow it to touch the bottom. My boys love putting ping pong balls in the bath when draining it. They also do it with a golf ball which provides its own unique bit of physics that you may find interesting.
Another method would be to use an upside down jar or glass to push the water level down and take the ball with it. There are problems though with how the trapped air will compress with depth and may not allow the ball to actually touch the bottom. Also capillary action would cause the meniscus to rise at the glass and the ball would slide to the sides if given enough time.
Regards,

There is a simplified solution at the end if you don't want to go through all of this:
Put the bowl on a big spring with a large spring constant. Compress the spring with the bowl on top as much as possible and let go. As soon as the bowl loses the spring it is weightless and so is the water inside and the ball. Thus buoyancy vanishes. Also there will be an initial lag in the transmission of the upward momentum to the ball and it will initially start dipping in the water as the water around it accelerates upwards.
Now hope that the spring let's go of the bowl (and the upward buoyancy force stops acting) before it overpowers the will (inertia) of the ball to go downwards.


OR

If the spring constant is really large, like infinite (a physics person's best friend), then the instantaneously infinite change in the bowls momentum will push the ball to the bottom.
For a more realistic system though I think the first solution would work.
Comments are welcome.

(1) The bucket riddle
I initially thought about how 25 degrees fahrenheit is below freezing but then thought about how long was the bucket left at that temperature, how heavy the king is and from what height were they dropped. My thoughts were on air temp rather than the temp of the water, and I was wondering how long a sufficiently thick surface of ice would take to form to prevent the wooden king from falling through. A long round-a-bout way of saying it would at least hit the bottom of the 25 degrees celsius bucket first, if it hit the fahrenheit at all, which it wouldn't as all water at -3.888C (this was Googled) would be solid ice.

(2) The clock puzzle
24 hr clock - 00.00
12 hr clock - 01.10 or 11.11 if they're like one of mine where it's displayed 1.10
Secondary thoughts; 00.00 to 00.00 is 24 hours.
Tertiary thoughts; Previous thoughts are somewhat rubbish, it's between 2 separate times, 24hr, 00.00 to 01.10 is 1 hour 10 minutes. Now not typed but running through other times.
23.32 to 00.00 is only 23 minutes.
12hr, 12.21 to 01.10 is 49 minutes if the first zero of 01.10 is counted. If not, 10.01 to 11.11 is 1 hour 10 minutes, same from 11.11 to 12.21.
So, 24hr; 23 minutes between 23.32 and 00.00
12hr (with 4 digits for all hours); 49 minutes between 12.21 and 01.10
12hr (without 4 digits for all hours); 1 hour 10 minutes between 11.11 and 12.21

I thought it required 4 digits. So a palindrome only requires all values to be reversed, 1.01, the last 1 becomes the first and the first the last with the 0 staying put.

BOWL RIDDLE ANSWER - place the entire bole on a spinning platform, and accelerate the spin until the water starts moving to the sides (ie, via centripetal force/centrifugal “force”). As more water moves to (and up) the sides of the bowl, the water level in the bowl will drop, especially in the center - which will drop the most. The ball, being in the exact center of the bowl will not move to the sides with water, but instead it will continue floating in the middle....and it will get closer and closer to the bottom of the bowl until it touches when enough water has been displaced to the sides by the centripetal force.

I have 2 methods:
1st, if you spin the bowl, the water surface will assume a paraboloid shape. Now spin it so fast that all the water goes to the walls of the bowl, leaving no water at the bottom. Because of the "tea leaves effect", the ball will stay in the center and touch the bottom! (You need a large bowl for that, lest the water spill from the bowl)
2nd, by the rules you can't touch the ball, but you can touch the water around the ball and press it down. Put a plastic (thin, flexible plastic) cup upside down with the ball inside, and push down. The air pressure will dislocate the water, but not completely because the air will compress (that's why you can't do it with a glass cup). Now crush the cup to compensate for the air compression, expulsing the air from the cup and making the ball touch the bottom.

25° C ist warmer than 25°F. How fast the King sinks depends on the density.

Obviously it also depends on the viscosity of the fluid, but this is probably almost similar and so the effect of it is very small.

PING-PONG BALL RIDDLE

Guess #1: Flip the Bowl
• Fill the bowl to the brim with water
• Seal the bowl with ping-pong ball (such as a lid, or really flat plate place on top)
• Flip the bowl
Assuming no water leak, the ball should touch the bottom of the bowl due the principal of matter density differences.

Guess #2: vortex
• Place your hand, or some utensil in bowl
• Spin your hand or utensil rapidly along the edge of the bowl
• Increase speed until a vortex is form at the center where the ball will be pull down to

Or

• Seal the bowl with a clear lid or cover
• Place bowl on any rotatable surface (such as a pottery wheel or spinning tray)
• Rotate the bowl until vortex is form, which pulls the ball to the bottom

Regarding chess piece in fluid:
If we try to sink the chess piece in a newtonian fluid (say propylene glycol at 25F and 75F), I think the question is whether you have the same volume of water or same mass. If you have the same volume, the colder fluid is more dense, and therefore would offer more resistance and the 75F bowl would "win".
However, if the mass of the fluid is constant, then we would have a higher volume of fluid to counteract the small edge gained by the lowered viscosity due to temperature, and both would be equal. Thoughts?

Bah, I of course assumed a 24 hour clock with leading zeroes, not a 12-hour clock. The question didn't specify.

For a 24-hour clock 9:95am is 09:59 and not even palindromic. I think this means the shortest interval is always 1 hour and 10 minutes. On either side of the middle you have a units column and a tens column. Obviously only changing the units by one is a smaller time interval than changing the tens column, and hours are longer than minutes, so you want to only change the hours by 1. This then means you HAVE to change the minutes tens column by one to get a matching half of the palindrome.

Thus 1 hour and 10 minutes.

I know the best way is to just use an empty glass and just put it upside down over the ball and then let the air pressure do its magic but here is a possible alternative solution. The weight of the ball is equal to the buoyant force on the ball when the system is at rest. So to make the ball touch the bottom of the bowl, all we have to do is to accelerate the system upwards with say acceleration, a then in the non inertial frame of reference of the bowl, the ball will have a "pseudo-force, ma" pointing downwards by newton's second law (ma + mg = pVg) where m = mass of the ball, p=density of water, V= volume of the ball and g = acceleration due to gravity. For the ball to touch the bottom of the ball the right of the equation should be greater than the left side. That is acceleration of the bowl upwards should be large enough to overcome the buoyant force on the ball when it is full submerged.

As usual, there's too many loopholes / vague rules...

- Take the ball out and touch the sensor from the other side of the bowl
- boil the water down to nothing
- tilt the bowl (depending how much water is in the bowl, the sensor on the bottom might go above the water surface)
- put a hole in the ball to allow water into it which would make it neutral buoyant but brings you much closer... boiling the water would make it bounce around in the bowl and would eventually touch the sensor
- remove the sensor from the ball and just drop it into the bowl, should sink to bottom
- scrape the sensor off the bottom of the bowl and apply it to the ball directly
- depending on the complexity of the sensors, you could use wires to touch the contacts / solder them directly to the ball to make it easier
- depending on the complexity of the sensor, you could just bypass it with a little creativity
- depending on how much water is in the bowl, you could also put a lid on the bowl and flip it which would make the ping pong touch the bottom of the bowl
- depending on how much water is in the bowl, you could also try a whirlpool effect
-etc... with vague rules and many loopholes, what's the point in asking us the answer?

Solution 1:
1. Put the whole works in the freezer.
2. Once the water is frozen with the ball embedded on top, flip the frozen block so the ball is on the bottom.
This works best if the bowl is narrow (or ideally a perfect cylinder), but even in a bowl-shape, I think if you waited, then the ice block would reach a point where it shrinks enough that the surface with the ball is small enough to touch the bottom of the bowl, and there is not yet enough thawed water for it to float above the bottom.

Solution 2:
